eyes by due representation of the other features. A 
lost look of devout abstraction in an uplifted coun-
tenance may be exchanged for an appearance of 
inquisitive archness in the leer of a younger face 
turned downwards & obliquely toward the opposite 
side. The under eyelid which in the former 
position conceals a portion of the ball of the eye 
from an effect apparently of mere perspective, will 
in the latter seem raised with effort, & thus gives 
the appearance of a smile to the same eyes, if 
supported by corresponding expression of the rest of 
the countenance. But it is needless to pursue 
the various modifications of which this experiment 
is obviously susceptible. The instances already
